Yeah, I think that something really powerful happens when you approach R&D or development from a bottom up rather than a top down kind of perspective.

I think that there's one world where you can imagine a lot of the research being done in the space being instigated by like monolithic organizations that have top down research agendas, which they hire researchers for, and then manage them to hit specific research outcomes.
And I think that this early on in a technology's lifecycle, a technology so early in promising as Ethereum, we can't predict.
No single person can predict what the most interesting directions are going to be.
And so we rely very heavily on our community and we frame ourselves as largely in service to a community of people who are really owning their own visions.
So, what we try to do is we try to educate folks.
I think there's a lot of similarities here, for example, with ETH Global, but we take people in, we try to educate them in a lot of these new tools.
And then we have some general areas that we think are interesting to explore, for example, like zero knowledge, machine learning or something like that.
Let's take a machine learning specialist, teach them how zero knowledge works, and then leave it to them to start to articulate like a research agenda or vision for that sub domain.
And then our role starts to become like connecting them with the experts on the cryptography side, or providing financial support via grants or educating or those kinds of things.
So, I think the community driven development here is really important.

And then the core of the project funding is this really neat mechanism where you take inputs from a whole bunch of different people in the form of contributions to projects that they value, and then quadratic funding.

The CLR mechanism essentially spits out an allocation that reflects both the preference and the strength of preference of all of the individuals in the community that contributed to projects that they value.
In the context of ClearFund, I think the community's biggest input is that it's helping to allocate funding to public goods.

What are the challenges that you are facing?
What was the start?
For us, we are building on really novel technology.

Ethereum itself is a very novel technology and then we are taking that a step further, building on top of zero-knowledge proofs using Macey, this minimal anti-collusion infrastructure, built by privacy and scaling solution to a team funded by the Ethereum Foundation.
It is bleeding edge technology. It is really incredible. It allows us to run a quadratic funding round or more generally run a vote in a way where the inputs are secret and you have no receipts.
So you cannot tell how I voted. I cannot tell how you voted.
Because of this quality, it makes it much less effective to attempt to collude to bribe to coerce people into voting or contributing in a way that is different from how they would like to.
But building using this stack of novel technologies that are upgrading frequently and not yet ordered, not yet being tested at scale, is a constant challenge.
We run into hiccups and roadblocks and whatnot constantly.
But I think that is part of the challenge. That is part of what we can have signed up for when we are building on this stack of novel technology, on novel technology, on novel technology.
And the reward is really worth it. Ultimately what we are creating is this system for permissionless, trustless, and private voting and quadratic funding,
which is a really, really powerful tool to enable all kinds of communities from the Ethereum community to the broader Latin American community and outward and onward from there.

- Brian. - Yeah, I'm going to maybe highlight another dimension of some of the challenges that these kinds of orgs might face.
So I think that in crypto and Web3 broadly, there's this massive iceberg of value creation across different levels of the stack,
whether that be from community management or from maintaining infrastructure, open source software, research and development,
that kind of thing. And only a small kind of relatively small tip of this iceberg is capable of being value capturing.
And so one thing that is just a difficult problem to face is the incentives problem of, for example, if you have folks coming into the ecosystem,
how do you get them excited about contributing to all of that core infrastructure that actually kind of powers everything?
Like it's both from an incentives perspective as well as from a fairness perspective as well as from a resource allocation perspective.
It's not necessarily going to be sustainable if you have people coming in and there's a ton of work being done by open source developers,
community managers, educators, a lot of grant money coming in from nonprofit foundations to help support or instigate these new kinds of,
whether it's like product directions or whatever else it is. And all those resources come flowing in and then afterwards,
like a venture capital firm like swoops in and sort of takes kind of like all of the upside from that and it goes up to all these LPs.
And not saying like there isn't, like that capital markets are not important, they're very important actually for driving specific types of progress and innovation.

But then there's this big looming question around like how do we continue to incentivize people to work on the things that power this whole thing that are kind of under the surface that don't have as direct of a value capture mechanism.
And that's one thing that we've been trying to think hard about and I love these experiments like Protocol Guild and everything that Clear Fund is doing around supporting these public goods.
Popularizing those mechanisms is just as important also as the technology that powers them.
